Title.evidence: Title: Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Cricothyrotomy Techniques

Trial_Design.evidence: A randomised crossover trial was conducted

Participants.evidence: Participants were emergency physicians (EPs) and trainees trained in both techniques.

Intervention.evidence: compare the time to lung insufflation between a surgical technique using a bougie/endotracheal tube (ETT) and an open technique using the Melker catheter.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to compare the time to lung insufflation between a surgical technique using a bougie/endotracheal tube (ETT) and an open technique using the Melker catheter.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the time to first insufflation of the artificial lung.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was achieved via block randomisation with random block sizes.

Blinding.evidence: Participants were not blinded to the technique.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Thirty-six participants (17 EPs, 19 trainees) were randomised to perform both techniques.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Thirty-six participants (17 EPs, 19 trainees) were randomised to perform both techniques.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The Melker catheter technique was quicker, with a mean time of 29.2 seconds compared to 44.3 seconds for the bougie/ETT technique (difference 15.1 seconds, 95% CI 10.8â€“19.4 seconds).

Trial_Registration.evidence: Trial registration and funding details were not provided.

Funding.evidence: Trial registration and funding details were not provided.
